zuul/configloader.py.message: I think this is currently safe as written because we only ever modify the list itself and not the list contents in the portion of code that will have contention. Thinking out loud we might want to consider using something like queue.Queue to be explicitly thread safe to avoid any problems should the code change in the future?

The basic structure here hasn't changed for some time, and I think "accumulate list of jobs to wait on" is a simple and well-defined enough use case to just rely on the atomicity of job.append (and worth the simplicity in this case).
Nit, in the zuul context an executor is the thing that runs the CI/CD jobs with ansible. Might be more clear to call this tpool or similar just to avoid confusion.

True.  We call it "process_worker" in the executor itself (though that's also a little misleading, since it's a ProcessPoolExecutor which itself has workers).  I like tpool/thread_pool (and maybe process_pool) for future work.

zuul/zk/__init__.py.message: Does this need to happen in a loop? I'm just wondering if there is one race here can there be multiple failures one after another?

Shouldn't be necessary -- the case with threads [A] and [B] is:
[A] Attempts to update it; fails because it does not exist
[B] Attempts to update it; fails because it does not exist
[B] Creates it; succeeds
[A] Attempts to create it; fails because it does exist
[A] Updates it; succeeds

As long as nothing is deleting it (and nothing should), an alternative circumstance shouldn't arise.

From https://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-November/018853.html the coordination backend isn't required, even just adding the cluster configuration will help. You could set the skip_backend_check variable and be happy if you want.

The two things that are still unclear to me:

2. Can we handle upgrades better? i.e. in some automated fashion?
Let's also finish testing the interaction with https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/767951 first before approving.

We should definitely allow for fallback support.
Some companies aren’t willing to use additional solutions such as the required additional K/V store.

Additionally, as already discussed on IRC, kolla purpose isn’t to enforce opinions on platforms.

As such, as cinder active/active isn’t enforced by Openstack itself, it should be an opt-in option as for the rolling upgrades already are.

Oh and we could also provide a way for ops to opt-in using memcached as K/V store for coordination as Tooz allow its usage.

ansible/roles/cinder/templates/cinder.co.message:
2 things to handle:

1) It should only be set for ceph-volume.
2) It should be set per cluster. Let's not assume that all cinder-volumes belong to the same cluster and instead let users decide per host. Do not get me wrong: I think that most of the time it will be the same cluster (with Ceph only at least). However, let's not wreak havoc if it is not the case. Also, notice this turns on clustering for *all backends*. I.e., enabling Ceph suddenly makes other backends try active-active HA only to fail (see https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/kolla-ansible/+/847352). Also, other backends than Ceph might benefit from this setting (netapp, pure). I suggest we only document the way to get active-active HA and not force it on users at all. WDYT?

  name_or_id = self.params['name']

ACK

just curious, didn't you want to use proxy layer like? 
  self.conn.compute.keypairs(**filters, allow_unknown_params=False)

Nope, search_keypairs() allows to pass filters which will be applied after retrieving the results from OpenStack API which self.conn.compute.keypairs() does not. In this particular case the benefit might be debatable but i would prefer to follow a clean pattern across *_info modules.

allow_unknown_params=False is not required because list_keypairs takes care of it.
Ref.: https://github.com/openstack/openstacksdk/blob/ba96fe850787edff38c053b8d1c2dfde401bb81c/openstack/cloud/_compute.py#L114

Adding 'name' to filters works here even if 'name' is an id because SSH keypairs in OpenStack have no IDs, only names. openstacksdk uses the keypair name as the id.

Ref.: https://opendev.org/openstack/openstacksdk/src/commit/af86313c83f631d212ffc0a14e4bf00a6d058582/openstack/compute/v2/keypair.py#L47

While the proposed change wouldn't block the deployment, but simply warn the user. I don't think it would create issues during the deployment per se.. If they are using parameter_merge_strategies, I would assume this warning would be well understood and not concerning for that user.

Maybe something in tripleo-validations would be a better place for something like this.Then it can be optionally used and not add additional complexity to the deployment process.

My main concern with doing this at all is that it's fairly computationally expensive to iterate over each line in each file. Might not be noticeable for <15 environment files. But if we had a large number of environment files each with a large number of parameters. It could become noticeable

tripleoclient/utils.py.message: is the intent to check for dup params in the same file, or across all files? looks like this just checks in the same file?

Yeah, my bad. New patchset coming.

Intention is to check all of them and report duplicates from any of the provided environment files.

The remaining problem that I can see is that if the value is in more than 2 files, it would warn twice for the same param:

```
Duplicate key detected: BoolTest. Applied value will be: False
Duplicate key detected: NtpServer. Applied value will be: ['192.168.1.221']
Duplicate key detected: BoolTest. Applied value will be: False
Duplicate key detected: NtpServer. Applied value will be: ['192.168.1.221', '172.20.10.22']
```

So I probably should handle that scenario better. In this case, I'm testing with 3 environment_files that all have those BoolTest and NtpServer parameters:
`environment_files = ['./test_1.yaml', './test_2.yaml', './test_3.yaml']`
Or just don't report what the applied value will be and only report on the files that contain duplicates.

swift/common/middleware/proxy_logging.py.message:
What are the pros/cons of this vs. adding Host to access_log_headers_only?

Though I'm realizing it'd be nice to have those values anonymized per-header...

It wasn't our main reason, but in fact we should anonymize this field because it can contain the bucket name in a virtual style.
The main reason was to be able to isolate this field to be able to process it (filter, sort, extract, count, etc.) more easily in the logs.
In addition, at OVHcloud, we use the LTSV format to be able to search (by field) the logs.
This is discarded, yeah? Which is why we won't bother looking for SERVER_PORT like we do in https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/swift/common/swob.py#L850-L854

`HTTP_HOST` can contain a port.
Which is why the other codes remove this part:
- https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/swift/common/middleware/domain_remap.py#L147
- https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/swift/common/middleware/s3api/s3request.py#L618

How will this interact with domain_remap? How do we *want* them to interact? I could see good arguments for either of the obvious approaches:

* Log the base domain, so we don't duplicate information from account/container
* Log the full domain, so we see what the user actually sent

I *think* we'd get the first given our recommended pipelines -- given the possibility of exposing account/container, should we use a StrAnonymizer here?

I don't use this middleware, so I admit I didn't think about it.
On the other hand, I agree that this field should also be anonymized because it can contain the bucket name in virtual style.

tests/unit/test_v3.py.message:
Change #2 ran with a dynamic config created with the contents of the repo which say to run "project-test", so it ran that job.  That tests the main part of this new feature: "don't bother loading static config for this branch, but instead create a dynamic config every time".

Change #3 is a proposed change to overwrite the in-repo config so that instead of running "project-test" it only runs "project-dynamic".  That tests that even when we're doing the main thing this feature adds (which is treating static config as dynamic) we also still support changing the dynamic config.  In other words, this tests that dynamic config works in the way it normally does on proposed changes to zuul.yaml in all cases.
I think the docs confusion also leads to some confusion here. Why isn't project-test also running if it ran on the previous change at line 8157? Seems like it should've have run there?

doc/source/security/kubernetes/manage-lo.message: Managing Composite(?) Local LDAP Accounts at Scale

REWORD:

The purpose of this playbook is to simplify and automate the management of composite Local LDAP accounts across multiple DC systems or standalone systems.  A composite Local LDAP account is defined as a Local LDAP account that also has a unique keystone account with admin role credentials and access to a K8S serviceAccount with cluster-admin role credentials.  

A user with such a composite Local LDAP account can SSH to systems' controllers and:
- execute Linux commands (with local LDAP account credentials; with or without sudo capabilities), 
- execute StarlingX CLI commands (with its keystone account (admin role) credentials) and 
- execute K8S CLI commands (with credentials of a cluster-admin K8S serviceAccount).

A unique Local LDAP account and unique keystone account enables user-specific command audit logging for security and tracking purposes.

Besides creating the required Local LDAP, Keystone and K8S accounts, the playbook also fully sets up Keystone and K8S credentials in the Local LDAP user's home directory on all controllers of all systems (i.e. standalone systems, DC SystemControllers and DC Subclouds).

The playbook can be used to create or delete such composite Local LDAP Accounts, manage access to sudo capabilities and manage password change parameters.

python-k8sapp-openstack/k8sapp_openstack.message:
I understood that you reordered the imports alphabetically, but just checking: the idea behind bringing sysinv imports before k8sapp_openstack imports is to bring external imports before internal imports?

This comment applies to most files, I'm not commenting this on every one of them.
Just a small correction, it's stdlib imports first, then 3rd party (that would include libs on requirements.txt since they come from pip) and then project-level imports.
Exactly, please check the flake8-import-order documentation for the "google" style at https://google.github.io/styleguide/pyguide.html?showone=Imports_formatting#s3.13-imports-formatting

Its because k8sapp_openstack is this package.

The way we typically do import order is

system level imports first (ie:  import os) (these can also be whatever we have in requirements.txt)

3rdparty imports next (this would include sysinv)

local imports last

.gitignore.message: This is a git improvement to facilitate design work. No worries.

This is an improvement for git to ignore the PyCharm auto-generated .idea folder.
Otherwise git will mark it as untracked, and we have to either manually delete it everytime, and lose the PyCharm config, or we have to add each changed file individually.

I don't think this is really required.
The PyCharm is an specific IDE that one can use or not, that's a personal choice and we should not mix specific IDE code to the repo code here, IMHO.

About git, what's the big deal on having that IDE specific dir untracked? One could simply not add the .idea/ files to any commit and life will go on.
remove .gitignore from the gitignore or the changes on it will never get to the repository
Marking as unresolved, this last version of gerrit assumes too much.

But if someone have the intention to actually add a new folder to .gitignore it [1] won't be staged and/or [2]will conflict with the .gitignore a user has on every pull/sync. We don't want either of that happening.

Btw, I'm not against the .idea on the .gitignore. Anything that would avoid me wasting time with unwanted things on a review LGTM.
OK, while we dont have a better solution, lets keep tracking the .gitignore

As per git documentation, a gitignore file specifies *intentionally untracked* files that Git should ignore. Files already tracked by Git are not affected. 

Having said that, marking .gitignore as untracked means that one can mantain the list of intentionally untracked files, without being tracked by git. There is no need to track the files (in repository) which are  *intentionally untracked*. From git repository perspective, these will simply "not exist".

Indeed, the selection of the Ingress chart was due to the fact that it is the first chart to be deleted in WRO removal time sequence.

Rephrasing> The *sequenced* property is false because deployment must go in parallel, since there are mutual dependency between the charts within the compute-kit group. manifests/backend/reserved/staging.pp.message:
I'm reading the glance release note [1], and from what I can tell the two reserved filesystem stores (tasks and staging) may need to use different data dirs. If that's the case then should we require users of this puppet class to explicitly configure these parameters (this one, plus the 'tasks' one)? If we allow $::os_service_default then that might inadvertently lead to users deploying these reserved stores with the same data dir, which [1] seems to indicate should not be done.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/glance/src/branch/master/releasenotes/notes/rethinking-filesystem-access-120bc46064b3d40a.yaml#L55

The default value of filesystem_store_datadir is overridden when registering these reserved store and different default values are used 'by default', so we can use $::os_service_default here.

https://opendev.org/openstack/glance_store/src/branch/master/glance_store/multi_backend.py#L133-L135

what's the reasoning for supporting both?
I feel like we should be able to make this switch entirely zed, and as such we don't need a parameter for it, just to remove it later.

No, we (at least I ;)) don't desire to maintain both long term - 1 cycle max.

The ability to switch things will allow to not break the whole CI. A bit like docker vs podman.

That said, in this case, there aren't that many differences, especially since iptables is, actually, iptables-nft, calling nftables. We're just shortening the path. It should be a fast switch, but I'd rather be on the safe side, not all scenarii are tested with the current jobs.

this param will make easier to switch on the CI side. I'm OK to drop it from the undercloud.conf, but here, we really want to be clean and have an easy way to switch things job by job imho. It's supposed to work as-is, but if there are some weird rules being pushed by some obscure job... Though I don't see what they could be. Still - the ansible role supports both by default. Probably better to add the switch here, and be more agile.

IMO Oleg has very good point that keeping things in different places may cause problems and forgeting about it in the future.
According to Liu's concern about development speed it shouldn't be any problem as You can always temporary do something like:

    of_tables = lib_const.INT_BR_ALL_TABLES + [MY_NEW_TABLE_CONSTANT]

This seems like a bogus question. No matter where such BR_ALL_TABLES lives, people can forget to add new entry to it. The reason is not where the BR_ALL_TABLES resides, it is people who have no enough backgrounds to acquire the detail. But people can forget anything, so upstream needs code reviewers. Anyone who adds new tables for ovs-bridges to make neutron ovs-bridges doing stale flows clean-up during restart, so those must take strong reposibility to tell ovs-bridges new tables are added to their BR_ALL_TABLES. Otherwise, do not touch anything related to neutron ovs-bridges. So, forget things must not happen. In another view, add a new table to BR_ALL_TABLES, but do nothing in real bridge code. This should never happen as well. People has no backgroud, just add new tables to BR_ALL_TABLES, because they JUST saw that other tables are in that list. But it is not used in neutron. So how to prevent that?

And remember, the main real cause of "to do things in different repos.." is because such constants file movement. I am against such move, especially when the entries are used only by Neutron itself.

So here, to make things simple, this line can still be "of_tables = constants.INT_BR_ALL_TABLES". Let "_ALL_TABLES" lists stay where it is. New tables can still be added there, and move to neutron-lib someday. Or when so other project real needs it, do a move work.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/807977/1/neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/agent/common/constants.py#90

I think we should agree if we want to avoid conflicts among table numbers (for br-int, br-tun and br-phys) between networking projects. If such conflicts are possible then we should care - and I think it's clear that we need to store table ID constants in neutron-lib.

Do we know if such conflict already exists? Or maybe not a conflict but just some networking project adding new table to br-int/tun/phys?

I'm doing that movement for a TODO [1] of qos constants. But you can not prevent people add new code to that TODO [2] list. It is a side effect of "rehome work of qos constants". I can see an endless loop of such work. Some constants are moved to neutron-lib, some added back, some new constants are added to Neutron with TODO, moving, waiting for a release of neutron-lib...loop...

Again, my only suggestion is we should leave Neutron used only constants in Neutron side. If some projects really need it, they take responsiblities for doing the movement works.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/804380/6
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/neutron/+/803045/15/neutron/services/qos/constants.py

IMO the best way to avoid colision long term is to keep all in neutron-lib. Otherwise we will be out of sync at some point for sure.

Of course it should be added with "TODO" note to rehome such new constant to neutron-lib. We are doing that for other things as well and it works just fine IMO.

People has no backgroud, just add new tables to BR_ALL_TABLES, because they JUST saw that other tables are in that list. But it is not used in neutron.

of_tables = lib_const.INT_BR_ALL_TABLES + [MY_NEW_TABLE_CONSTANT]

Code looks good for me but I think it deserves release note too.

When passing multiple connections for servers on different machines, it makes no sense to add a Connection DB entry for them. Each server would try to connect to *each* of the addresses listed in the Connection table, and would fail to connect to the ones not on that machine.

If you add addresses that a server can't listen on, ovsdb-server will try to connect to those servers many times every minute.

Normally, with RAFT you'd pass the --remote ptcp:y:x.x.x.x option on the CLI to set up the listening address--but, there is no way to set the inactivity_probe with that currently.

One way to do this correctly would be to create a *local* db for Connections, and pass that second DB to ovsdb-server since it can handle multiple DBs per server. Then set the individual connections in that DB on each raft cluster member for nb/sb db and pass that db/table/column as a remote, e.g. --remote=db:Local_Connection/Global/connections. Note that it is currently not supported by the ovn-ctl script to pass a second db (though you can cheat and pass it in --ovn-nb-log and --ovn-sb-log).

Example script to create the DB and populate it:

    https://paste.openstack.org/show/814966/

Which you'd run by:

    ./setup_connection_db.sh $ovn_db_dir/connection_nb.db ptcp:6641:$ip $inactivity_probe
    ./setup_connection_db.sh $ovn_db_dir/connection_ns.db ptcp:6642:$ip $inactivity_probe

This patch is technically fine since it doesn't create connections and if for some reason someone wanted to listen on multiple addresses on the same machine it would work? Though I'm not sure why one would connect to multiple addresses on the same machine, so I think we should consider reverting it.
recheck

The problem is that when you have ovsdb Connection entries for each of the machines (listening on different addresses) then ovsdb-server on *each* machine tries to listen on every Connection row. If you have 3 machines, this means each of them will try to listen on 2 connections that they don't have interfaces for and will keep trying to listen on those addresses many times per minute.

Here's an example log: https://paste.openstack.org/show/bvXxxbFduUi4XwuI5M8C/

hi terry, I don't know if I understand you correctly. this patch is mainly for ovn cluster deployment, rather than multiple addresses of one machine. 
When deploying an ovn cluster, neutron should configure the addresses of all members of the cluster. Otherwise, ovn nb/sb may not be connected because the configured address is not a leader node.

Here is an example of ovsdb-server being angry trying to listen on an address that is not on the server:

https://paste.openstack.org/show/bvXxxbFduUi4XwuI5M8C/

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Arguably, the bug is here -- I think I understand the logic of why we did it the way we did (it was simple and eased rolling upgrades), but if we

- saw that the remote seemed to support shard ranges,
- actually attempted to sync shard ranges with it, and
- hit an encountered a timeout or other error doing so

it seems reasonable to abort replication at that point. That is, the two ways you could arrive at shard_range_success=False in https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.29.1/swift/container/replicator.py#L105-L114 should perhaps be dealt with separately; perhaps something like

 if 'shard_max_row' in rinfo:
     # Always replicate shard ranges to new-enough swift
     shard_range_success = self._sync_shard_ranges(
         broker, http, info['id'])
     if not shard_range_success:
         return False
 else:
     shard_range_success = False
     self.logger.warning(...)

doc/source/configuration/block-storage/p.message: This phrase is an English colloquialism that may not be readily understood by all readers. Perhaps replace with "access or modify..."
Done
or a "system-scoped" token to act upon the Cinder system itself.
Done
This one catches me off guard.
yeah, until we enable scope by default and that is not configurable then we can introduce more persona in system scope like system_reader, system_member etc
Well, this is for Zed.  The Zed policies need to work whether enforce_scope is enabled or not; if it's not enabled, a user with the 'reader' role would be able to read system-scoped stuff.
Just a quick thought, for consideration. You could add another column to indicate whether the persona was implemented in Xena or if it's new for Zed.

I actually started to do this, but the problem is that the system-admin persona is introduced in Xena, but will have different powers in Zed if we proceed with the strong system API/project API split, so I think the "release introduced" column would be more misleading than helpful.

So this is an interesting situation. Looking at [1], it does seem the User Messages are project-oriented. Are we concluding User Messages won't ever be associated with the Cinder system?

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/src/branch/master/cinder/message/message_field.py
Yes, the User Messages are explicitly designed for communication with end users (the idea being that a cinder administrator has access to the logs, where there is more detailed info).

What's the thinking here?
- It seems odd that a system-admin can list them, but cannot do anything with them.
- Conversely, it seems odd that a project-admin can manage a snapshot, but cannot find out it's manageable (by listing the ones available to manage).

Maybe this just means the system-admin and project-admin (assuming they're not the same person) are forced to collaborate?

Yes, it's a forced collaboration.  The system-admin can list them, since they're not associated with any project, but a project-admin will have to actually manage them into a project.  (Not sure how workable that will be in practice.)
The use of "Mixed" is a good way for readers, and reviewers of this patch, to locate the "interesting" policies. It conveys the need to pay attention when the policy's scope is mixed.
Ack

Hmm, yeah. Does a project's quota affect the system? If it does then this feels like a system-admin thing. But if it only affects quotas *within* a project, then it would only seem to be a project-admin's business.
Yeah, I'm really not sure about this or the next one.
ditto.

See my previous comments about manageable snapshots. Something feels off to me when a system-admin can list which volumes can be managed, but they cannot manage any of them (L1350). Conversely, a project-admin can manage a volume (L1349), but they cannot get a list of ones that are manageable. As I noted before, is this a way to force the two admins to collaborate?
Yeah, the idea is that the system-admin will hand a project-admin a list of volumes to manage for the project(s) of which that person is a project-admin.  (Not sure it's a *good* idea, though.)
That's a good question. The legacy rule was "admin or owner," and I don't recall why we would preclude a project-reader from seeing this.
Yeah, I can't remember whether we had a reason for this, or just missed it in Xena.

What's the benefit to a project-admin to see the list of projects that have access to this type?

And if a system-admin has no business knowing which projects have access to a type, then I guess I've lost track of the use cases for this API method. Who does it serve?
Good question, and I am not sure.

Maybe we need to handle this in a manner similar to "user visible extra-specs." It's reasonable for a system-admin to have some knowledge of the volumes, but /detail will return a lot of the data that's clearly project specific. Conceptually, we could filter the data in the response when the context is system scoped. Not sure if it should be coded that way, or if we should add another policy to control whether project specific details are returned.
Yes, this is a place where the pure system-scoped vs. pure project-scoped breaks down.

This is another aspect of the same consideration. It's reasonable for a system-admin to have access to *some* volume information, just not all of the the project specific details.

Maybe the topic should be highlighted in a note?
Yes, I meant it as a comment for reviewers to discuss so we can decide what to do.
I don't have an answer, but we need to decide. It's an interesting question, but for expediency we might just kick the can down the road and leave the question for another day.
What's the response when a project-admin specifies another project_id? I assume a project-admin should only be able to query their own project, so a 403 response seems correct to me.
Why should a project-admin see the default volume types for other projects?
I was thinking maybe to see what the popular types are?  Maybe this should be a 'no'?
I agree, a system-admin should be able to see this.
Ack

> Also, the commit message suggests a link is being added, what does that mean?
Just bad wording :) - The idea of this change is only to monkey patch paramiko

> Is this approach being pursued in any other project?
Yes, it is:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tempest/+/822560
But it is only until we can get the pull request Ade proposed into paramiko.

Goutham,

The problem is that paramiko is incredibly slow moving.  There are currently 226 open PRs, some up to five years old.  If we have to wait for paramiko, we could be waiting for a very long time indeed.

Given that paramiko changes so slowly, its unlikely this will change anytime soon - or that the change will be much different than what is here.  The change is actually quite small.

If it does change in a breaking way, we'll know right away because of broken FIPS enabled jobs, and we'll be able to fix it.  For stable branches, we can always constrain the version of paramiko.

Finally, as we move towards FIPS compliance (rather than  just compatibility), we're likely to either replace paramiko, or provide the option to use a different FIPS compatible library.  At that point, we could remove this monkey-patch.
Sorry for the misleading commit message :/
tempest is a branchless project - it worries me less if something breaks with tempest; if we decide to do this, we'd be leaving this in code potentially forever in a released stable branch...

    # NoteTLSData has been deprecated/removed in rocky and onwards

I am very much against this proposal. Most of my serious concerns are in the comments of the various "impact" sections.

In short having "admin only" API which use case is service-service interaction opens such a massive can of worms we cannot afford to deal with.

Second part of my concern is related to the consuming services. It took years for Cinder and Nova to adopt Images API v2, I don't expect anything less for this meaning that we would need to carry both approaches in the codebase for foreseeable future.

Most of the issues that this proposal is trying to address could be addressed by adopting service tokens with minimal changes in the consuming services (If I understand correctly, both Cinder and Nova has the concept already in place, so this would be matter of including the service token to the calls rather than refactoring all the handling) and maintaining the authorisation of any said activities in Glance with full traceability.

Should this proposal move away from the admin-only nature of service-service communication, I'm more than happy to lift my -2 and continue discussion.

I suggest putting this the other way:

When show_multiple_locations is False, non-admin users cannot modify image locations via the image-update API call, even if they have the {get,set,delete}_image_location permissions.  However, there are some popular use cases where other services can bypass Glance and store or access image data directly in the backend by writing or reading image locations, using the image owner's credentials, and this is why operators want to set show_multiple_locations to True.  What operators want to do, however, is to enable optimized image data access; exposing image locations to non-admin users is a side-effect, not the goal.  We currently recommend that operators who want to use optimized data access use a specialized Glance instance for services, and only expose glance-api to end users with show_multiple_locations set False.  This is obviously a cumbersome and unsatisfactory solution.

For API that is expected to be used for Service-Service calls this is horrible idea as it requires admin credentials (that are unlimited by their scope in Open Stack) to be stored in the calling service.

Compared to the current situation we will loose traceability of who has performed these actions in logs as all the operations on project owned resources would be made using an admin account.

As adminnness is all powering, there is no authorization who can perform said actions to the project owned resources in Glance side. All the Authrisation is expected to happen in the service calling these APIs.

There is very little expectations of actual human admin performing these actions rather than service performing them. This means that leaking or not of any sensitive data is fully dependant of the consuming service. As the expectation is that the consuming service is calling these on behalf of non-admin user in Glance point of view, this is always leaking sensitive data as we have no control of the authorisation.

> For API that is expected to be used for Service-Service calls this is horrible idea as it requires admin credentials (that are unlimited by their scope in Open Stack) to be stored in the calling service.

Compared to the current situation we will loose traceability of who has performed these actions in logs as all the operations on project owned resources would be made using an admin account.

We will move to using service role when it is implemented in keystone, until then we only have the option to keep this admin only to avoid the security threat.

> As adminnness is all powering, there is no authorization who can perform said actions to the project owned resources in Glance side. All the Authrisation is expected to happen in the service calling these APIs.

> This means that leaking or not of any sensitive data is fully dependant of the consuming service. As the expectation is that the consuming service is calling these on behalf of non-admin user in Glance point of view, this is always leaking sensitive data as we have no control of the authorisation.

There is a difference between a non-admin user calling glance directly to do location operations and a service (like cinder) does this on behalf of a non-admin user for an operation like upload volume to image. In the latter case, Cinder is responsible to ensure that a volume entry exists on behalf of the new location added and performs all the checks around that so we can be assured that the location is not Fake and in the former one, the user can do anything.
Even though the service calls glance on behalf of non-admin users, the non-admins users can't randomly demand Cinder to add/remove locations, the control is still with Cinder and not non-admins.

Even though both of these are not being implemented right away, I still think that having a unique identifier in the GET result is prudent. If we add update/delete in the future, then instead of just allowing those operations, we also have to change the behavior of GET to enable it.

I also think that returning the full location from POST, with the generated unique identifier creates the proper client behavior workflow of "Create a thing, grab the identifier", even if there's no immediate need at the moment.

Having APIs that are supposed to be RESTful that are designed in a way that they *cannot* be RESTful without changes is not very productive, IMHO.

Not a hard -1 thing for me, but I think we should strongly consider "doing it right".

Well, he said he didn't see the need for it, but it didn't seem like he was necessarily very opposed to it.

Years of experience cleaning up problems in nova that stemmed from exposing row-correlation primary key IDs to external users tells me that it is absolutely a terrible idea to do so. Just because imageid+id is unique doesn't mean we should expose those, regardless of whether or not they're only ever referenced within the scope of an image.

Anyway, you've cut down the functionality of what you're proposing here to the point that it doesn't _need_ the unique ID part, so there's no point in demanding that you do it. However, if it were me, I'd just go ahead and do that now so that we're not substantially changing the API later. If the argument is really that integer IDs are better, I'll be glad to further support that position, and if the concern is over the work required to add and test them, then I'm also willing to help with that part.

But again, I acknowledge it's not critical for this first pass, so I shan't die on this hill :)

My biggest concern is how heavy the migration operation will be, even being just one-off task. For a cloud that has thousands or tens of thousands of images with potentially multiple locations on them updating every single one having uuid, not because we need one but because it would be cool to have one, is not exactly something I'd be happy to force in.

I agree with what you said but introducing the unique identifier has conflicting opinion from different reviewers. Initially I tried to introduce a new UUID field in locations table but Erno has the opinion that our current ID (integer) field combined with image id acts as a unique identifier (see previous patchsets for reference). The unique identifier was important before for update and delete call but going into this discussion without any current use seems exhausting. I can add the integer ID field (which we currently have in locations table) as a response for add, get if you agree with Erno's opinion but if we plan to add the new UUID field, it will be a whole new discussion and will also increase the scope of work, testing and possible regression cases which I would suggest to do as a followup. let me know what you think.

I understand the data migration issue, and would definitely not recommend the naive approach of converting everything all at once during an upgrade. In other projects we have millions of resources that have to be updated in the same way. The established practice for something like this is to migrate-on-load.

A pre-existing thing doesn't need a unique identifier until it's examined, so any time we load a location record (due to an API request or other action that looks at it), if it doesn't have an identifier, we generate one, save it back, and then continue on. From the outside, it looks like everything is already migrated, but in reality it just happens when we look. Like "Schrödinger resources".

how do we know that the pod is started on this host vs standby or multiple?

It was observed that it takes around 15 sec (with the minimal load running in my lab) to restart the container. The controller-manager pod's running status is always 'Running' until container is being restarted. As the container restarts (say at nth second), the pod is restarted at that nth second when the container is restarted, until then the pod shows 'Running' status. (These time durations may vary depending on the workload in the cluster) So checking with pod's Running/Ready status may give false results. So it was preferable to check the container's running status over the pod's status. The container and the pod runs per controller. So it is checked per controller. I hope it answers the question.
Just to elaborate, "crictl ps" only shows containers on the current node.

We considered that, and it would be much simpler, but would add a fixed delay on the playbook execution. With the current approach it will wait less time or not wait at all if resources are already Running, for example on the following log it waited ~4 seconds:

TASK [common/armada-helm : Check ingress validating webhook service and pod status] ***
Friday 17 June 2022  13:02:56 +0000 (0:00:00.810)       0:22:05.228 *********** 
changed: [localhost]

Friday 17 June 2022  13:03:00 +0000 (0:00:03.973)       0:22:09.203 *********** 
changed: [localhost]
could this now be 'command' instead of 'shell' with the native kubectl params?

No, because command module does not accept pipes "|" that it is using to replace/delete some characters from the service.spec.selector.

Module doc says: "The command(s) will not be processed through the shell, so variables like $HOSTNAME and operations like "*", "<", ">", "|", ";" and "&" will not work. Use the ansible.builtin.shell module if you need these features."

Source: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/collections/ansible/builtin/command_module.html

See specific comments inline.  Additionally, I have one general question I'd like you to address: do we have to worry about a volume being placed into two groups that have competing requirements?  What I mean is, is it possible that by putting some volume in Group A and Group B, the user will bring about a condition such that it's impossible to use both A and B?  (We haven't had to worry about that before because it couldn't happen.)  Your proposal is focused on how we can keep track of a volume being in multiple groups in the database, but are there other issues we need to worry about?

Thanks, Brian for taking the time to review, and sorry for the delayed response.

Volume can be part of multiple groups if the groups are of a different group type. This means We can have the same volume to be part of snapshot-enabled and replication-enabled at a time, and both groups can be used for the requested operations. But if the volume is part of replication-enabled group1, then it cannot belong to another replication-enabled group2. 
So GroupMapping APIs have to take care that volume is added to the allowed individual groups.
Agree, apart from making changes in the database to associate volume to be part of multiple groups. There are other changes like Block device mapping group API's, which also need to be modified to take this into account.

The primary issue here is how this changes the Block Storage API.

1.  The volume detail response currently contains a 'group_id' field that's defined as a string (in practice, a UUID).  We can add a new microversion (say 3.69) that includes a 'groups' field that's defined to be a list of uuids, and we can define mv 3.69 so that 'group_id' is no longer included in the volume-detail response, and only the 'groups' list is included.  

2. But if someone requests a microversion < 3.xy, then we need to put something in the group_id field (it can't be null because that would mean the volume is not in a group, which may not be the case).  I guess we could put the first group in the group_id field. though I think we need to get a warning to the user that the volume is in multiple groups.  I wonder whether we could use a special UUID (maybe all zeros?), and then adjust the group-detail response so that when someone calls GET /v3/groups/00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000 , the description in the response says something like "A volume with this group_id is contained in multiple groups.  Use microversion 3.69 in your volume-detail request to see the list of groups it's in."  (I don't know if that's a good idea, but it's something to think about ... somehow we need to address this problem.)

3.  If anyone is currently relying on getting a 4xx back from the update-group call to prevent them from putting a volume into multiple groups, they will no longer be able to rely on that behavior.  (I don't think there's anything we can do about that other than mention it in the release notes and the api-ref.)
